title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. This account is considered a transaction account unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Act is amended to clarify that no institution prohibited by law can offer demand deposit accounts. The amendments will take effect two years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Prohibition on Payment of Interest on Demand Deposits and Joint Rulemaking Required for Authorization of Interest and Dividends on Transaction Accounts at Depository Institutions. Regulations required by this subsection shall establish the scope and types of transaction accounts to which authorization applies, including limitations and restrictions. The regulations must take effect within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. Definitions for "depository institution," "transaction account," and "Federal banking agency" are provided. The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Act will become effective either 2 years after enactment or when final regulations under subsection (b) take effect. The term "Federal banking agency" is defined in section 3 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. SEC. 4. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with regulations set by the Board on payment and distribution of earnings. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank. Depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility have responsibilities regarding the crediting and distribution of earnings. The term 'depository institution' includes trust companies, corporations organized under section 25A, branches or agencies of foreign banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank. Amendments include authorizing pass-through reserves for member banks and making technical and conforming changes to the Act. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to give the Federal Reserve Board more flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than 8 percent (including zero). SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions at depository institutions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The curr_chunk discusses benefits that may result from actions taken by depository institutions regarding escrow accounts.
